text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm web cantaloupe cayenne sorbet
that's right when I saw this flavor
being featured by one of San Francisco's
top ice cream makers I of course assumed
they were huge fans of the show and this
was some kind of homage well as it turns
out they'd never heard of me and had no
idea what I was talking about but
regardless it sounded amazing so I
decided to find the recipe and it
actually came out better than it sounded
this really was incredible so I'm very
excited to share with you and we're
going to get started by prepping our
cantaloupe and all that means is we're
going to cut it in half and of course
scoop out the seeds and then we'll
simply use a spoon to scoop out that
gorgeous sweet orange flesh and ideally
what we want to do here is scoop this
into a bowl set on top of a scale
because what we're going to need for
this is exactly a pound and a half of
cantaloupe and I do realize we're
usually not that big on exact
measurements but if we want to get a
really nice texture we have to make sure
the ratio between the fruit and the
sugar is correct so like I said we're
going to scoop out exactly a pound and a
half actually you know what let's make
that exactly a pound and a half plus 3/8
and then once our fruit has been
successfully scooped in weighed we'll go
ahead and add that to a blender and for
whatever reason if you don't have a
scale if we smoosh this down in the
blender you can see it's about four and
a half cups of cantaloupe
but either way once that's in the
blender we can continue on with the rest
of the ingredients the first of which
would be some white sugar and by the way
I have a prediction someone will leave
the comment that's a lot of sugar which
is of course so dumb but anyway after we
add that that's a lot of sugar we'll add
the juice of one lime freshly squeezed
of course so so far nothing too unusual
with these ingredients but that's about
to change because next up we're going to
add a little splash of seasoned rice
vinegar which may seem a little strange
for a sorbet but it totally works so put
it in and then after that believe it or
not we're also going to add a couple
tablespoons of vodka which if I'm not
mistaken is an old Alton Brown trick and
I will attempt to explain what that does
on the blog post but I want to be clear
it's not to catch a buzz there's not
really enough for that it's for the
texture and then last but not least the
co-star of the show some cayenne and as
usual the exact amounts going to be up
to you you are of course the Stevie Ray
of your sorbet so this really could
range anywhere from a small pinch to the
quarter teaspoon you see me adding here
so you really should add some otherwise
you
have to change the name of the recipe
but anyway once we have all our
ingredients in the blender we will go
ahead and blend this on the highest
speed to completely liquify it so give
it a minute or two we really do want it
as smooth as mechanically possible and
if everything's gone according to plan
when you're done your mixture should
look something like this and I guess you
could taste it if you want but you're
really not going to get the full effect
until it's frozen and then once our base
is set of course we have to turn this
into sorbet using one of these my
handy-dandy small but very effective ice
cream maker so we'll go ahead and pour
our sorbet base in and proceed as they
say according to manufacturer's
directions and while these machines are
fairly inexpensive and you really should
get one there's like a thousand
different hacks posted online for how to
make ice cream without a machine so
check those out there really are a lot
of alternatives that work quite well and
by the way as this is spinning try not
to eat it all by tasting it every two
seconds okay I'm only doing this so you
can see how the texture changing is as
spins you know for scientific reasons
but anyway we're going to go ahead and
at that turn until it basically turns
from a liquid into sort of a slushy
sorbet okay these machines are never
going to freeze your ice cream or sorbet
completely solid otherwise you're
probably break your machine okay once it
gets to this stage you're pretty much
done you'll actually hear the motor of
the machine start to labor so what we'll
do is stop and we'll take a spatula and
we'll quickly scrape down that white
paddle thing which probably has an
actual name everything does but anyway
we will clean that off to kind of smooth
out that surface a little and then all
we need to do is cover this in plastic
and pop it in the freezer until it's
firm which because I had a video to
finish I didn't exactly do so I popped
in there for a while but the mixture was
still a little soft which really was not
a problem except I did have to do a
little cleanup for the pictures so do as
I say and not as I did let yours freeze
until it's firm you'll have a better
texture but having said that even a
little bit soft this was incredible I
mean the first thing you get is that
beautiful fresh sweet cantaloupe which
is just beautifully enhanced by the
tankiness from the vinegar and the lime
juice and then right at the end as
you're swallowing that awesomeness the
heat kicks in oh-hoo-hoo the heat that
little bit or more than a little bit of
spiciness to Cayenne provides makes us
one of the most addictive sorbets I've
ever had and yes in case you're
wondering this will work beautifully on
a cone in fact if you're keeping score
at home I think it works better on the
cone because not only does that crunch
provide a beautiful textural contrast
that sweetness from the sugar cone
really balances the spiciness
beautifully this really was fantastic
and as you know I don't throw that term
around loosely but anyway that's it
cantaloupe Cayenne sorbet not only is
this an amazing summer treat it's also a
bit historic since I don't think we've
ever done a video that had the word
Cayenne in the title I know I can't
believe it either so for that reason and
many many more I really do hope you give
this a try soon so head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
